title: What is the role of psychology in education? - Quora

response.answer_text: Role of Psychology in Education. The word psychology relates to the relationship of mind and behaviour of different individuals. This behaviour is not static and is constantly in a flux. It is almost impossible to predict as to how a particular individual will behave in certain circumstances. Scientists have studied behaviours of large populations and have generalized the outcomes. We all develop a mind set for certain situations but it can change with time. Certain chemicals called “Narcotics” from different origins can temporarily alter our conscious behaviours and induce feelings of higher bliss. But they are addictive and can damage the normal functions of brain and cause mental illnesses. Usually people after suffering serious losses in life seek out these narcotics and then the downward spiral begins. They end up becoming costly social burden. Now let us strictly focus on the field of Psychology as applicable to education. Education is a knowledge which is acquired formally or informally in order to lead a normal social life. It is a life long activity from cradle to casket. Every organized society expects its members to show behaviours which are considered to be the norms of the society. Serious deviations lead to trouble and legal consequences. A child explores the world around him through the senses of touch, taste, sight, sound, smell, and stores that information in his mind. He picks up the language skills without learning its alphabets or grammar. He is educating himself and is being educated by the people who come into contact with him. In his mind he figures out that to taste an apple, he needs to bite, chew and swallow. There is a relationship between his thinking mind and the behaviour outcome of feeling not hungry. The parents are his primary teachers before he goes to school. A child’s brain takes quite a while to grow and develop. Before the age of 19, he is considered a child and his undesirable social behaviours are condoned. But after that age, he is treated as an adult and faces sanctions which may not be pleasant. School or college education is a formal education where teachers are involved in imparting knowledge in different subject areas to enable him to become a professional to earn a living and serve the society in which he is growing. Teachers have to have a good knowledge of human psychology in order to avoid the conflicting behaviours of students. Some students may be constant disturbance in the smooth running of a course. Teachers learn educational psychology in their training and use it to their advantage. If the disturbing students are given a role to lead others in some ways, they settle down and become allies to the teachers. The contribution of distinguished students are also recognized by awarding them prizes and special honours. This encourages positive behaviours for the groups. In the industrial world, a large amount of money is spent on advertisements to change the mind set of the consumers to buy their products. They use the psychology that by repetition and beautiful presentation of their goods will encourage the behaviours of the masses to purchase what they want to sell. It is obvious that both formal and informal education is a psychological approach to control the behaviour of the masses.

Psychology is the scientific study of human mind and behaviour. Psychologists work in many different areas of society and are concerned with practical problems. Below are only a few examples: Helping people to overcome depression, stress, trauma or phobiasEasing the effects of parental divorce on childrenSpeeding up recovery from brain injuryHelping to stop or prevent bullying at school or in the workplaceEnsuring that school pupils and students are being taught in the most effective wayMaking sure that people are happy at work and perform to the best of their abilitiesHelping the police, courts and prison service to perform more effectivelyHelping athletes and sports people to perform betterFor more information about the discipline, check out our ten things you might not know about psychology section. Many of the challenges we face in the modern world are rooted in human behaviour, so psychological knowledge can help us find solutions. People with all sorts of problems seek the help and support of psychologists. For example: Adult mental health problems Every day counselling psychologists and clinical psychologists help a wide range of people of all ages with all sorts of problems. Some people have particular emotional or mental health problems, such as depression or schizophrenia. Others have difficulties with their thinking, which is also known as ‘cognitive’ problems. These can take many forms, such as problems with memory or perception after a head injury, a learning disability or dementia. There are many more areas of life where a psychologist can help. These could include helping people manage and live with health conditions such as HIV, cancer or chronic pain, assisting people who have difficulties in maintaining relationships or providing advice about how to care for a child who has been abused. Whatever the problem, the psychologist will consider what scientific research says about its probable cause and what will be likely to help. Sometimes the psychologist will be the one who then provides the help. Examples of this include seeing the person for a number of sessions to provide psychological therapy or giving advice on how to manage memory problems. Sometimes the psychologist will recommend other people who can help, perhaps advising them on the best way forward for the client.
